												Carrier Command: Gaea Mission is ultimately a good (not great) game that blends strategy, tactics and action, but it suffers from the most god-awful annoying campaign I think I have ever played.You'll hear a lot about the bad bad BAD script and voice acting, but the campaign is terribly paced too, being, as it seems it was intended, a very, very long tutorial for the Strategy Game option. Having said that, I persevered with the Campaign, and after you take Fulcrum and push into the enemy's territory, which is around the same time you unlock missiles for your Mantas—and around the time the AI starts pushing back!—the game finally lives up to its promise and gets awesome.Taking the islands become a real tactical challenge each time, and your strategy of which islands should be Production, Mining and (oh so important) Defense becomes critical to success. When you get to that point, the Campaign is actually pretty good and the game finally lives up to its potential.Whether or not you can stick it out that long is another story...I have a LOT of love and nostalgia for Carrier Command, having played it ad nauseum on my Amiga when I was a kid, but without that good will, I'm not sure I would have had the gumption to push through the bad bad BAD start of the Campaign game. If you can, though, I think you'll find you are rewarded.Subjective Assessment: 7/10

												+ Very nice graphics.+ Command interface is easy to use.+ Various gameplay improvements over the original.- Tacked on "story" mode.- No multiplayer.- Broken pathfinding.The GoodThe original Carrier Command, while primitive by modern standards, was a really good game for it's time. A good combination of strategy and action. BIS has rebooted this game and fixed many shortcomings of the original's design...well, almost.First thing I will say is that the graphics are very nice. There is a "film grain" effect you cannot turn off, but that aside, I have no complaints whatsoever. The models of the carrier look awesome and the animations are pretty solid. Good job BIS!The interface has also had a huge overhaul since the original. Commanding units is very easy to do (once you get the hang of it). I get a feeling this was designed with consoles in mind, however it works fine on PC, so again no complaints from me.I'd also like to praise the unit customisation added to gameplay. You can now outfit your Mantas and Walruses with different armour and weaponry to engage threats more effectively...but sadly, this is where the praise ends.The BadThe story mode is just a glorified tutorial with bad voice acting. Some parts of it are good for learning the game - the sole reason I played all the way through it was to prepare me for the REAL game; Strategy Mode.The lack of multiplayer is also quite disappointing. Why this was not implemented is not clear - some forum posts suggest it was axed due to development costs, other say it was to be added in a later patch. I personally suspect the former was more likely the case. Either way, it's a pity as multiplayer could have probably boosted the sales of the game.The UglyThe Walrus pathfinding is so bad it's not even funny. Mantas are OK, but Walruses have trouble driving in a straight line. I've tried every patch released since day one and some third party mods, but nothing works. I'm not exaggerating here, feel free to look it up on YouTube.Final ThoughtsThe pathfinding is the deal-breaker for me. The lack of multiplayer and the lame story mode I can forgive, but not this. The amount of sheer frustration I've had just trying to get units to get from point A to point B is too much. It's highly unlikely that BIS will ever fix this - they've released seven patches already and still can't get it right.VERDICT: Don't bother.

												I won't critize the game for its poor production values (voice acting, facial animation, animation in general, props, textures), but I will critize its A.I. because the game is based on it.You see, if you make A.I. movement a core component of your game, you'd better make sure your A.I. systems and pathfinding are at least generally competent - capable of doing basic tasks. The A.I. in this game can be called many things, but "competent" isn't one of them. Which is a problem, because if you have to manually move every single unit because it manages to get stuck every 200 metres, the game becomes a chore (this gets borderline hilarious at the first muddy island - the one where you get the flying unit for the first time - where a more complex level topology and mud makes for a physically painful experience instead of fun). Now don't get me wrong, programming competent realtime A.I. is one of the hardest programming challenges, but that's the thing - if you can't do it properly, don't even try, because it will end badly. They could have try to work around the A.I. by designing the game differently, instead they went in guns blazing and just failed to deliver...

												Back in 1988 a company known as Realtime Games created a game called Carrier Command for multiple home computers such as the Amiga, ZX Spectrum, and Commodore 64. A crossover between a vehicle simulation game and a real-time strategy game, players were tasked with colonizing multiple islands in an archipelago and destroy the enemy aircraft carrier before they can colonize the archipelago themselves. The game was well received receiving high marks from various publications, and gaming magazine The Games Machine even awarded it the number one game of 1988. In 2012 Bohemia Interactive released Carrier Command: Gaea Mission, a modern remake of the original Carrier Command. Did the game hold up over all these years?For starters, I’ve never played the original Carrier Command, so I can’t really compare the original to the remake.  From what I can tell, the main goal of Carrier Command’s campaign is to take control of various islands on the planetoid Taurus in a war between two factions: the United Earth Coalition and the Asian Pacific Alliance. The Campaign portion of the game starts out with you leading an attack on a moon called Taurus in an attempt to take control of it for its resources, to help sway the battle against forces who have taken over Earth. Unfortunately something goes wrong and your squadron crashes on the moon and only a few survive. From there you set out on foot with another soldier who guides you as you roam about in a FPS-style game. Your first goal is to make your way to a damaged carrier. You will venture through a very linear path with just one gun, shooting at very generic looking robots. After this short and dull FPS sequence, I came across the first vehicle in the game. My squadmates started directing me how to control the vehicle and what I could do with it. I found that controlling it was difficult using a mouse and keyboard, so I switched over to using a game controller, where one analog stick steered and the other aimed my gun. Playing with a controller honestly felt more rewarding. Your ground vehicle’s health, fuel and ammo could be topped up by just driving up to various refilling stations shown on the map and pressing the right button. Topping off the vehicles various items is quick, which came in handy when you are on the run. You have two viewing choices when moving your vehicles: a first person or 3rd person view. I stuck mainly with the third-person camera angle because you need to see more of the surrounding area so you don’t suddenly find yourself sliding down a hill, out of control.After becoming familiar with your new toy, you eventually make your way to the damaged carrier, dock at its side, and make your way inside. Once again you are back on foot in a short FPS segment taking out more robots. After all the robots are cleared, the surviving soldiers join you on the carrier, and you take command of the ship which turns out to be completely remote controlled, so you don’t need to leave your command chair. However, the carrier is badly damaged and in need of repair. So from your new seat you are able to remotely control the vehicle that brought you to the carrier.  You wil then drive it to the nearest island on your map to search for supplies. This is where the game’s focus shifts to the main campaign where you will be taking over various islands you come across by hacking into base computers. I quickly found that this is not that simple because all the islands have defenses in the form of ground roaming robots, vehicles, as well as small and speedy airships. Not to mention most of the bases have gun turrets. Much of the time you will be running around activating switches to shut things down to gain access to areas and bypass enemy defences. Different islands have different properties: some have production facilities which will produce new equipment or vehicles; others are rich in resources that you need to repair your carrier and produce your equipment. There are up to 33 islands in the game all with various environments. Some can be swampy, others more temperate and others more desert-like. In the swampy areas it is really hard to control ground assaults as you slip and slide in the mud and wet grass. This is where a real time strategy-like gameplay element comes into play as you dive deeper into the game. Some islands get tricky and require you to have more than one vehicle on the go. You can have up to four ground and four air vehicles executing orders at the same time, each equipped with various guns and devices that you produce to aid you in taking over the island in question. I found the AI for the game as a whole to be very hit or miss, with spots of brilliance followed by some completely bizarre behaviour.Other than the main campaign, you have one other mode called “Strategy Game”. Here you are pitted against the computer in a large randomly-generated battle, but you have various settings at your disposal like the number of islands, enemy strength, what resources you start up with and how fast islands generate the materials you need. You can also set winning conditions too, like a number of carriers destroyed, or islands that need to be taken over. It’s a fun mode if you want to avoid the single player story and get into the thick of things quickly. In terms of the visuals, the game is nice to look at, but nothing blew me away. Weather and environmental effects are nicely done and you can see a bit of influence from the ARMA series in it. I did experience some weird clipping issues while driving vehicles. I would be driving along and suddenly part of the screen would flash like I drove through something. The music in the game is odd. It’s very big and orchestra-sounding with a large choir, but it only plays at certain times. The rest of the time it’s just environmental sound effects mixed with sounds of vehicles and gunfire. Voiceovers from the characters work quite well, and no one seems to be overacting their roles, but as you progress through the game you do get somewhat tired of hearing what they have to say.For a game that attempts to mix in some First Person Shooter sequences with some Real Time Strategy elements, Bohemia Interactive did a decent job. Unfortunately, the overall experience falls a little short due to some of the issues with the AI as well as the lack of any multiplayer and some technical issues.

Carrier Command: Gaea Mission - game with a huge, perfectly wasted potential. This is one of a few games in my library that I regret much about not just buying, but even wasting time on completing it. Why this game not worth to be bought:*This game buggy…very buggy, even after six patches*Story campaign dull and boring, with cliched plot, poorly made dialogs and mediocre voice acting.*In-game tutorials (if its possible to call them that)  poorly done and explain nothing*Terribly done, consolish graphics*Awful, in a worst sense, arcade physics*Dumb, ineffective AI*Horrible tactical control options*No multiplayer support, even LAN or splitscreen*No real integration with Steam services*Huge price tag for such crappy productIf you wish to play real 'futuristic carrier sim', buy much better 'Hostile Waters: Antaeus Rising' or 'Battlestations' dilogy. If you are interested in quality tactical games - stick with original 'Operation Flashpoint' or 'ARMA' series.'Carrier Command: Gaea Mission' - not a tactical game at all, its an awful arcade TPS with just four available commands that you can issue to a nearby troops, while global commands via tactical map could be issued only to one unit per time. 												This game is very under rated... It is a mixture of tactical gameplay and action gameplay and works really well. It falls short of being a masterpiece because of a few issues, but it wasn't too far in my opinion. I mostly play the Campaign so haven't done many Skirmishes. The story and voice acting is quite low budget, but the focus is on the gameplay anyway. The music is great and the graphics are nice. The controls and physics are good in this game, vehicles feel solid, weight affects their speed so what you equip them with has an impact, they slip on mud, they struggle up steep hills and whizz down the other side etc. It is realistic and handles well. The gameplay overall is good but not great. You have to capture a series of islands, so you travel there in your uber Aircraft Carrier, and then you launch some flying pew pew pew craft to scout the island and work out where all the resources are etc. The flying craft are weak though so you have to use them to scout carefully and then get them back to safety. Later in the game you get to use them more to shoot or bomb key targets, but early in the game they are only really used as scouts. Then you launch your tanks which will do all the capturing. You can have 4 tanks and each one can have a few gear upgrades of your choice, heavier armour that makes them slower but tankier, a variety of weapons, a hacking device, etc. The campaign is slow to get going, the first dozen or so islands you have to do with basic gear, but it gets more interesting later on when you get to start using your carrier's big guns, and your units get more interesting weapons like the gattling gun and your can drop bombs from the flying units etc.Capturing the islands is done by driving around and capturing mini bases all over the island, and killing anything that gets in your way - preferably by waiting for your squad to keep up with you so you can get the benefit of all their firepower at once. Sometimes there are fixed turrets shooting at you, sometimes a bunch of robots come at you, and sometimes some vehicles or aircraft come at you. Occasionally you have to deal with all of those at once, but you can tend to pick stuff off bit by bit if you go slow and steady, especially earlier in the game. Also you can park your flying craft nearby and you can use those to help you finish off stuff once the main defences are dead. This capturing of the islands is the bulk of the game and it is fun, but this is the part of the game I think should have been a bit better. It isn't bad by any means, but it could have been better, and there other bits of gameplay I think they should have ignored and instead just focused on this part of the game. You also have to manage your carrier in the meantime, building gear to replace whatever you lose in battle, and generating more fuel, etc. There is a little bit of strategy with the island capturing too, because you can choose if the island should produce stuff, mine stuff, or be a defensive island, so depending where on the map it is, you can use this to your advantage. Although the game doesn't seem to focus on this enough in the Campaign at least. Overall it is fun and actiony, but it does fall short from greatness in several ways and I'll try to explain. First off, as you can see from a lot of the negative reviews, some people try to play the game as a tactical RTS type game. Technically the game should have let people do that, but the AI just isn't up to it. The way I play is to take direct control over the main tank, and set the other 3 tanks to follow me, and the game plays fine like that. You somtimes need to wait a moment for them to catch up, but mostly the pathing is fine and the AI does ok at following you and shooting whatever you shoot. The problem is if you want to sit back at the carrier or fly around command the ground units from afar, like a real strategy game, bad things will happen due to pathing and AI failures. They AI and pathing is not terrible, but it isn't good enough to just send things off on their own and expect them to make it. Often they will get whooped by the enemy or stuck on a tree, tumble down a cliff etc.. It is a shame because it could have been a bit more RTS. Personally I don't really care about this though, because if you lead the troops into battle (surely this is the most fun thing to do anyway?), they will follow you just fine. Also the actual capturing of the islands (which is the bulk of what you do) is quite repetitive and shallow and could have been better. Each island might have a different shape, but they all work the exact same way. There are several bases on the island and you have to hack a building or clear out the enemies in each base, and on to the next one, and then you can capture the command center in the final base. Do that then it is on to the next island to repeat, in exactly the same way. It is a bit more interesting in that you unlock better gear as you make progress, and in the campaign especially, this can make the game quite addictive. You start with very basic basics, and gradually you unlock many little upgrades. Also the enemy bases start getting tougher and more interesting as you progress through the islands. At first it is just a handful of guys who die with 1 shot. Then you start getting occasional tanks, but later you get fortress style bases with many turrents, ambushes of several enemy tanks, and flying craft all over the place. The game is repetitive, but at least you are repeating fun things, so not a major problem, but to me this is the bulk of the game and it could have used something to jazz up this basic combat.Lastly, there are some wasted opportunities. Clearly they just didn't have the time or budget to do everything they wanted, but it is a shame because there are things that could have fleshed the game out more. Like I said you can customise the islands to do what you want, but there should have been more to this. Also you can actually shoot things from your carrier, but you very rarely get to enjoy this because most of the stuff on each island is inland so it is out of your range. Also you can choose priorities of repairs on your ship, but this hardly ever gets used so it is like a wasted feature. Also you can put different weapons on your tanks but the game doesn't really require you to play smart. The sensible option would be to have 1 of each weapon, so the lazer can blow up stuff, while the anti air cannon guy can you protect you from flying stuff, etc.. etc.. But really, just the lazer alone is enough to deal with everything. Also there are a few FPS on foot sections in the game but they seem a bit weak and gimpy compared to a real FPS. They are not terrible, but a far cry from Halflife 2 or System Shock or something. So there are a lot of under developed features, and I think the game would have benefitted hugely from the devs scaling back all this stuff, and focusing on the key gameplay and making that great instead of ok. Overall it is good game though, and quite a unique experience. If you want deep strategy, or visceral action, look elsewhere. But a blend of both those things is not often seen so this game is worth thinking about. I wish it had better sales because a bigger budget sequel to this game would be a big deal in gaming, especially nowadays. I think the game really suffered from limited marketing, I never even heard about this game until years after release.

												While I have never played the original Carrier Command, I have played games of similar genre, specifically "Hostile Waters", Carrier Command: Gaea Mission (CCGM), a remake of the original Carrier Command, tried to add some new elements, but ended up a confusing mess. At its heart, CCGM is a real-time strategy game where you conquer islands with your land and air units, taking direct control if you have to, or leave AI to accomplish your orders. An enemy carrier is doing the same. However, CCGM added a few segments where you have to play first person shooter. You sometimes have to control a vehicle directly as well... which makes you wonder "why am I risking my own neck? I'm the captain!"The developers, Bohemia, added some backstory where the UEC is fighting against the APA (apparently mostly Chinese), and UEC is losing, due to lack of water, so they decided to colonize this "Taurus" planet, take its water back to Earth, but obviously APA is there to stop them, and apparently they got there first. You, Lt Myrik, is ordered to land and hopefully make your way to an old carrier, reactivate it, and use it to help you reconquer the islands in the "Dead Zone". The problem with the game is while the starting islands (first 4 or so) do introduce the game to the RTS player, the really important part of the game, such as setting up defenses of the island, so it can survive assaults while you're out island hopping, is left virtually unexplained. You're simply told that you can convert the islands to 'defensive' by building a "defensive module" and rebuilding the command center, but that was too vague. And it doesn't explain how to actually IMPROVE the island's defense rating, which ranges from weak all the way up to "deadly". The ship itself also needs fuel which is also used for damage control / repairs. And the only way you can get fuel to carrier is through fuel packs sent via the cargo barge (submarine) which can also bring you various other goodies from your "stockpile" island where all the stuff your manufacturing went. Transport capacity is limited, and it takes time moving from stockpile to you (and back). The more islands you conquer, the faster your resources accumulate or the faster your manufacturing goes depending on what type of island you got. Pathfinding is a major problem in this game. The AI units have a tough time pathfinding in groups, which makes the game at times, comical. Often you have to assume direct control to push the unit beyond the chokepoint, then the AI does a decent job of pathfinding, but it can't manuever around other friendly ground units. The atrocious pathfinding means you have to micromanage each vehicle for fuel, ammo, and repair, rather than give simple orders like "group fuel" or "group ammo" and see the units take turns by themselves. The vehicles can often even get lost by themselves, often with hilarious results, not to mention some odd physics. Send a vehicle to go from one end of island to another, and it may end up falling off a bridge, or making a 360 turn when a simple left or right turn would do, or get stuck on some rocks. Once, one of my Walrus managed to turn turtle (upside down) in the middle of the ocean on the way to the island. Somehow that makes it move BACKWARDS instead of forwards. (Huh?)  Yet another funny is with the hook. Tried to retrieve a Walrus that ran out of fuel with the hook. Had to be flown manually, and I got too low and the Walrus is dragging in the waves... but I was flying with nose straight into the water, and my VTOL engines were pointing 45 degrees down into the water, yet I'm still moving across the water... dragging the Walrus along. Somehow the hook is still attached. Hahaha. The game tries to mix up the bits by giving you many First-person shooter segments. You need to actually jump out of the vehicle and use your personal weapons, such as assault rifle, laser, and later plasma rifle. Usually, you go into the enemy base and do your various bits of sabotage, raid computer terminals, and so on and so forth. There are a few segments where you have to jog across the whole island. You mainly face battledroids and a few soldiers, but occasionally, turrets and vehicle (but you usually bypass them. The bases are pretty easy as you do have a personal shield and as long as you don't take too many hits at once your shield powers up again much like HALO. However, some bases have regenerating enemies (until you shut that down) and you have to watch out for exploding barrels (which can kill you).  Those segments are just... weird, out of place, even. The end of the game, well, that gets ridiculous really fast. Spoiler ahead. To accomplish the end game, you need to...1) Conquer 2 out of 4 volcanic power plant islands that is supplying the big enemy bastion with shields that damages everything nearby. You need to check all four islands though. 2) Once you've disabled the shield, then you can start the invasion proper, but you're in an FPS segment, where you can take direct control of one of several Walruses, and the others will follow along as AI. You can jump out and change to a different vehicle. You have to secure 7 different "zones" on the island shooting all the bad guys. Fortunately, you do get a "repair walrus" to tag along and repair your squad if you conquer the first zone. 3) Once you secure the final zone (don't run into the forcefield!)  you have to drive up to the research center where you get the control software of the torpedo, and you enjoy a cutscene where the enemy carrier goes to the bottom, but the bad guy is getting away in a Manta (flyer)  so you jump in a Manta and follow him too. 4) The bad guy's Manta has a shield... yours does not. However, you do have a super gatling. You have to chase him amidst enemy defenses (all of them trying to shoot you down), without crashing your flyer into the hills or whatever, while you try to overload his shields, then shoot him. 5) Once you got him down to 20%, a timer starts. He goes one particular path, then heads for his submarine pen where he will escape. You have to kill him (shields and all) before he gets to the pen. 6) The game then turns into a "rail shooter" where you're the gunner and the AI drives, and you have to shoot enemies all along your path... UNTIL the next segment... when your vehicle's toast, but you survived. Then it's...7) Yep, back to first person shooter. Fight your way across the bridge, down a mountain pass, to the submarine pen, for the final cutscene. The game is also quite happy to crash here and there. I'm on a pretty standard setup and the game crashed many times, losing a hour or two of progress each time. Most of the time autosave works, but sometimes, the game just crashed when it tries to load a cutscene. All in all, I should be playing Hostile Waters (which is now available)

												I haven't played very far into this game (see below for why), but man. I was a huge fan of the original Carrier Command back on my Mac Classic computer, and I was excited to see someone remade it. Until I actually tried to play this mess of a game.The game starts with a literally 45-minute-long inexplicable Halo-ripoff first-person shooter section that has absolutely nothing to do with Carrier Command and serves only to confuse the bejeezus out of players. It's also, frankly, not very good at all.If you get past that obstacle, you do finally get into the carrier's captain's seat, you know, that thing that should have happened in the first 30 seconds of the game. However, here the game somehow gets even worse.Your first mission is to take over an enemy island. Ok, fine, that's like 75% of the original Carrier Command's gameplay, so I should feel right at home here. To do so you move the carrier to the island. (Which, BTW, takes ages-- the game supposedly accelerates time, but even despite that it takes a solid few minutes to arrive.) Once there, you equip a Walrus amphibous vehicle with your only command center hacking took and get onto the island.Once there, you have to squint to find the white-on-light-blue waypoint markers the game uses to tell you where to go, assuming you notice them at all which I didn't for the longest time because they're so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed invisible. The Walrus you get lands with almost no fuel, so you first have to find a fuel station. It took me a long time to get past this because the tutorial never tells you:1) What the fuel station looks like (hint: lightning bolt icon)2) That you have to use F to "activate" it and actually refuel. I assumed I was doing it wrong because I was sitting there for ages and nothing happened.Once you've finished that obstacle, your next task is to enter the command center. If you take the direct path, you end up falling down a cliff, destroying the only hacking unit thing, and getting a Game Over. Seriously. This game could not have been playtested even one bit.During your next play through, you telepathically realize you’re supposed to continue down a road that looks on the map like it goes in the entirely opposite direction you want to go. When you do arrive at the command center, a force field seals it off, and here’s where the tutorial really goes off the rails.You have two Walruses and two buttons you have to hit at the same time. The solution is obviously to position one Walrus at each button, then press the buttons quickly to open the force field. The problem is: the second Walrus always follows the first one on autopilot when you switch! So it’s virtually impossible to get them positioned correctly! There are also a lot of quirks the game never tells you about—for example when you get into a Walrus you can’t actually steer it until you tap the throttle with W or S on the keyboard. Until you accidentally discover that, you’ll probably just assume the game is broken like I did. Again: no playtesting whatsoever.I did manage to finish this challenge mostly by accident. Then the tutorial voiceover lady tells you to drive into the command center, quickly get close to the building, and hit the F key to begin hacking. If you do that, you of course get another Game Over, because it’s the entirely wrong thing to do. What you need to do is go slowly, extremely slowly, past the base defenses because it turns out that while you’re hacking, if you get hit by even a single bullet, your progress is reset to zero. There's no point to even starting the hacking until you've taken out all of the robots and turrets defending the base. Of course the game doesn’t tell you this, and of course you assume the tutorial text is correct, so of course you get another Game Over. Then you come here to Steam and write a review of this worthless garbage game.I spent 40 minutes on the first damned mission and wasn’t able to complete it. Partly because the tutorial text doesn’t tell you important things you need to know. Partly because what the tutorial text *does* tell you is a lie. And partly because the AI actively fights against you when you’re trying to complete the level.Unbelievable garbage.

												Don't get me wrong, this game is of high quality and brilliant ideas. It has stunning graphic, the islands maps are so detailed and well made in order to suit vehicle gameplay that I almost feel like it would be a waste to manage all your units in the RTS map mode. 　But I wouldn't recommend it to others. It's just that I found the gameplay somewhat unrewarding and repetitive. Although you got lots of weapon and modification types, the basic structure of every battle is pretty much the same. You drive your carrier to capture an island, deploy 4 Mantas (hoverplane) and 4 Walruses (armour car) with various weapon and tools and head to the command centre. You don't have any other type of units except those two.　Although the campaign start with a FPS experience, you don't get to play as foot soldiers anymore after the first level. I was expecting the player to be at least able to walk around the commanding bridge of the carrier, staring outside the window as you wait and watch your units coming home, and I was disappointed. Even though you did walk around inside the carrier in the first level. 　You can't move your carrier in anyway besides the preset waypoints of warp positions. You can't direct control anything other than those 4 Mantas, 4 Walruses and a main gun on your carrier, dispite how many droids and turrets defences you own on an island and that even though you did play as a droid in the first level.　There are just too many little disappointments such as these, and too few variations or distractions to keep you entertained besides the main objective, which can be frustrating at times. The game really appeared to be an nice and huge open-world playground, but far too often I feel myself restrained in actual gameplay.　It's a well-made game coming from one of my favourite developers but IMO got loads of wasted potential. I got this game from humble bundle for a few dollars, along with ARMA series I believe, and it's well-worth it. But the full price of $32.99, I don't think so.

You can't direct control anything other than those 4 Mantas, 4 Walruses and a main gun on your carrier, dispite how many droids and turrets defences you own on an island and that even though you did play as a droid in the first level.　There are just too many little disappointments such as these, and too few variations or distractions to keep you entertained besides the main objective, which can be frustrating at times. The game really appeared to be an nice and huge open-world playground, but far too often I feel myself restrained in actual gameplay.　It's a well-made game coming from one of my favourite developers but IMO got loads of wasted potential. content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I have many fond memories of this game's progenitor when I played it on my beloved Amiga A500. The graphics were simple, but functional for the experience of tactical and strategic gameplay. The entire premise of the game was almost like a naval chess battle. When I heard there was a remake in the works I did have expectations that the core of the game would still be there, but in a very modern wrapping. The carrier itself has visually transformed and like all the visuals, is very impressive. The audio is good too, but the execution of this games core is poor. Blending first person shooter elements into the game helps take the stale out of being locked into vehicles, but there's no multiplayer to really validate it. The need to be moving in and out of vehicles and structures feels like a bolt on to a RTS game. Actual vehicle combat is good enough, The AI is thin, pathing for friendly vehicles is often poor, and I've had to manually retrieve a fair few Walrus that got themselves trapped. The enemy doesn't show a great deal more sense, and the challenge they present isn't in their tactics, but their numbers and loadout as you progress through the campaign. I was aching to get my carrier toe-to-toe with the enemy's. I loved brining down the ACC Omega on the original version, but the naval combat is almost pointless, it's mostly defending your own ship from island defences and when you do finally meet your nautical nemesis, you feel like a bug on a windshield. (The originals enemy carrier had weaknesses, the modern version only becomes vunerable after a certain point, beware of this)The two modes of play differ mainly in that one has specific story based missions and goals in a near linear campaign format. The other is more likened to the original, though it's best to point out here that it is a LOT slower leaving an imprssion that playing through it will be an immense chore. This game would have flourished as a multiplayer experience with players piloting or on foot, either in direct engagement or attacking/sabotaging supply lines. I had fun, but couldn't help feeling that they just didn't really go the distance with Carrier Command they could have.Good - Solid visuals, good management and vehicle combat can be a lotta fun.Bad - Cardboard thin depth of play and no multiplayer (and no real excuse for its absence)

												I know nothing about the original Carrier Command, so take this review with a grain of salt. Carrier Command: Gaea Mission is primarily a strategy game with first-person elements. What seems to have been an opportunity to harness a very gorgeous and expansive universe is squandered by clunky, non-functioning, or restrictive controls, a narrow and unchangeable field of view and, most egregiously, terrible AI. The fact that the voice acting and the sound effects are poor are nearly forgivable but the fact that the AI - an absolutely essential component of the game - doesn't work is this game's undoing. The AI, through commands that the player gives to units that operate independently due to this game's first-person perspective, should work well enough to perform the tasks delegated to them. They don't. Telling a unit to dock on the carrier does not guarantee that the unit will dock on the carrier. This is important when a unit that is low on health, the death of which means a game over in many cases, because the unit will not take anything resembling an "intelligent route" to the carrier. It will wantonly engage enemy units that it should try to avoid, making the AI entirely unreliable. This is not a good system, because micromanaging the units to the scale needed for them to do their jobs is unreasonable. Even worse, this game requires automated tasks like moving units back to the carrier, to continue the game, which may mean spending a long time just leading units back to the carrier after a mission. Once, I drove one unit manually while allowing the other to navigate itself. I got the controlled unit to the carrier, only to find that the AI controlled unit was repeatedly hitting the side of a bridge, wasting quite some time. These mindless tasks are piled on random tasks that do not serve the "story line" and are clear attempts to prolong the game, and the system that moves the carrier from map to map also takes a long time of doing nothing for absolutely no reason at all. Speaking of the story, the "Story-Driven Campaign" with its "immersive storyline" is more a very long tutorial. The story itself is initially very unclear and does not begin in any manner that could be described as “compelling”.I was excited when I first got Gaea Mission because it looked great and the environments look stunning. Unfortunately, that's the only part of the game that I can bring myself to like.

												Carrier Command: Gaea mission is a Real-Time Strategy game that also allows you to jump into either your air or amphibious land vehicles to capture islands with the goal being either to capture every island on the map and/or destroy your enemy's carrier, or at least that's how I understand it 6 hours in.Like the start of a rollercoaster, you'll start to anticipate how much fun you're going to have with this game: a tech tree (albeit randomized), logistics management, the cameras that show you what your unit sees.  Then the cart flies off the tracks when the Tropic Thunder A.I. that manages your pathfinding clashes with the enemy's Skynet's A.I..  Units equipped with grenade launchers will stand still point their guns in the air upon receiving a command to attack a structure, or straight up murder your own carrier if you deploy them to chase a nearby enemy unit.  Thankfully, the air unit's A.I. is on point, and probably better than your own flight skills.I would be amazed if you could lose an island at all to the A.I., as conquering an enemy island requires you to do a side mission, including fuse-boxing scramblers so that your units can reach the command center, or fuse-boxing firewalls so that capturing a center doesn't take five years.  It's 50/50 that your unit will reach the area and activate the point without getting stuck on a rock or tree.  Units even get tripped up on things as nebulous as water on the main map screen.  By the time you've spent half an hour taking an island the size of five minutes, the game crashes on the very next move you make.  If you won't save your money, at least save your game after every conquest you make here.The game makes other bizzare decisions: You aren't told how long an area you've captured will be ready for production.  You can't speed up time outside of running out of gas and trying to gun it to an island anyway.  An invisible tech tree that you make random progress in when you capture an island or click a factory.The other reviews here are accurate.  I'm not deterred by a few glitches here and there, but this game made me throw in the towel.

												Back in the late 1980's, there was a game called Carrier Command available on the Atari system in 3.5inch floppy disk format. I was only 4 or 5 years old at the time, so I wasn't able to fully grasp the concept of the game at that time. But I do remember enjoying many hours of Atari gaming with the original Carrier Command. So when I came across Gaea Mission on Steam, I just had to check it out.The playable demo did not disappoint. As the commander of a large carrier (hence the name, Carrier Command), it is the player's job to colonise numerous islands scattered within a vast archipelago. These islands can then be used to perform research and production of superior weapons and technologies that can be used to enhance the combat effectiveness of the carrier and support vehicles. Meanwhile, the opponent is doing exactly the same thing. War is inevitable, it's just a matter of how well prepared and equipped you are vs your opponent, when the time comes.Support vehicles consist of four aircraft (Manta) and four amphibious vehicles (Walrus). Each can be kitted out with various upgrades such as armour, weapons, sensors etc, some of which are only available for either Manta or Walrus. For example, Capsules enable the player to comandeer islands and can only be fitted to the Walrus. Similarly, the Hook allows the Manta to pick up and transport Walrus vehicles, therefore it can only be fitted to the Manta.Most computers may be out of their depth trying to run Gaea Mission on maximum settings, but a high-end gaming machine will have no problem. Having tried all the settings however, I can say that the graphics are still very attractive on the lowest setting. Either way, there is so much more depth to this game than I am able to portray with a brief review. So if you're a fan of the RTS genre and/or you've played the original Carrier Command and/or you fancy exploring uninhabited islands and/or you like my review, I highly recommend Gaea Mission.

												This game is pretty great. It has good pacing, at the beggining, it has you moving straight away without any kind of tutorial, but it starts off slow so it's not overwhelming or anything. The enviroments are just beautiful too. The number of islands there are to conquer is just astounding. Sure, they're not super big, but they're all special in their own way, and there's just so many of them. The driving mechanics is pretty well done, the first person shooting is kinda awkward at first, but it's not a huge portion of the game so far, and I have yet to try flying. So far I have to say it reminds me of Planetside 2 in it's graphic style and gameplay mechanics, but way bigger and single player. So yeah.

												Ok, so its not perfect.  Yes there are bugs.  Yes there are FPS issues.  Pathfinding/AI is utter rubbish!So?It was a grand undertaking to try and remake one of the best known sim/strategy games of its time.  I wasted days playing the original Carrier Command on the Atari 520STE.I was thrilled when I learned of this remake, but cautious as well.This game is great!  I have enjoyed taking the Manta's for flyby's and the walrus' for joyrides.  I kill things because they're on MY island!  Its great!If there are two things I dislike about this game (and I can overlook a lot of things) its: 1. No Jump Button 2. Cannot BUILD bases (at least not so far as I've seen)That’s it.  Neither of which are deal breakers.And to all those complaining about the "Campaign"?  Its a tutorial.  Its to teach you the basics of the strategy game.  Thats all.  It was never meant to be perfect.  But its better than a "Im your commanding officer, and Im going to teach you how to use the mouse pointer to select a unit" type tutorials.Its a fun game, that’s all.  Just a game that brings flooding back memories of yesteryear with much upgraded graphics.I hope that the dev's fix the few major bugs, but all in all, I like it :)Easily an 8/10, but if they fix the AI and framerate issues, then it would make this a 10 in my books.

												This game would have been more successful if it had more support from the developers. There is no hardware cursor option, making gameplay feel sluggish and heavy. Other than that and some laughable moments with glitches, it could be a decent game. The variety in gameplay is nice, the vehicles feel very different from one another. Though it may have been implied somewhere that there is first person shooter action in the game, this is true for the Storyline, but it seems to be absent for most if not all of strategy mode which is a different play option altogether. This game is for science fiction simulation enthusiasts, not your typical gamer.

												I got this game as part of a humble bundle. This was infact why I bought the bundle. Visually this game looks great. I was expecting something with the visual detail of something like FEAR 1 or 2. This was more on a Halo4 graphic level.Unfortunatly that's it, it looks cool but plays pretty badly. The mouse has no acceleration setting so it's quite difficult to aim and move and so on. I also found the lack of a jump button quite odd. (I like to do what tiggers do best across games)finally the voice acting, though clear and informative sounded like it was recorded in a garage. Also, everyone was very excited. "dude we are in a field, nobody is here, why are you shouting at me when im 2ft from you?"So, I wouldn't suggest buying this game unless you get it cheap like I did. They may work out some of the crappy bits in updates but for me it just lacks the polished quality I would expect when paying £20 for something.
